name: The Beginner's Guide
description: The Beginner's Guide is a narrative video game from Davey Wreden, the creator of The Stanley Parable. It lasts about an hour and a half and has no traditional mechanics, no goals or objectives. Instead, it tells the story of a person struggling to deal with something they do not understand.

This game is an emotional ride. It is one of the most perfect discourses on loneliness, illness, and perception/misperception. At only a few hours long, it is a succinct exposition on what it feels like to be alone, to be depressed, and to be anxious. Does that sound like a bad thing? Well, it's not. It's like a breath of fresh air to not only hear about these taboo subjects, but visualize them, feel the depth and breadth of them, and actually understand the yearning in it.   If you are going through a hard time, play this game. If you think no one understands you, play this game. If you need help with your own issues, play this game. Or if you simply want to be moved by another's story, play this game. It is eminently relatable to any and all. Unless you are an abiotic robot, ofc. :p  It's a very powerful experience. And it even offers a solution. Get it! Cheaper than therapy, lol.

Now you may ask why I compare this game to Stanley, and while you may be right, since they are different in a respectful aspects, similarities are impossible overlook. And they are not bad. I thoroughly enjoyed Stanley Parable and I instantly 'marked' it as incredible, unique, and a very memorable experience. Maybe my mistake was expecting more of a same with a bit of variety from this one, but unfortunately for me I was wrong.  Now, I'm not saying this game is bad because it's not Stanley, but I can't help but notice that the game tries to tell a story in a unique, but rather hollow way. I have to admit, certain moments left me speechless, and the story is quite intriguing, but it's not anything special. Why others people give this game such a high praise is beyond me, but I feel like the game has different impact which differentiate from a person to person. When it comes to me, story didn't pull me as much as I thought it would, but that's okay, and I'm more or less satisfied with what I got for the amount I paid.   This is not a bash on a game, given that I left a positive review, but merely a NOTE to NOT expect Stanley Parable 2. Just get into this game, and let it tell you its story. Hopefully you'll like it more than I did.

This game is a set of games made by a single developer, none of which were released. A narrator walks you through small projects, and attempts to explain the creation of them. This is how the story unfolds, by changing emotions portrayed through the atmosphere of the various games you play.  The narration through this is really quite incredible. In fact, everything ties itself together very well into a cohesive story, even though you are in drastically different games throughout your playthrough.    Perhaps a little too well, even. But, I'm going to continue telling myself that it's a true story, regardless.    There is also a very good representation of timelines, as the games improve in quality over time. Overall, everything was just really well done, and very well polished.  I can't remember how much I paid for this game, perhaps I paid full price, perhaps it was through some bundle somewhere. Regardless, it was definitely worth it.

Few games have stuck with me as much as this, and few games are as creatively daring. Effectively utilising a 'House of Leaves' like layered narrative in a way I've not previously come across in a game, The Beginner's Guide examines the need for social validation at its extremes, here in the context of the games developer and the player. Throughout it feels like a deeply personal work from its creator (whoever that may be!), and at times you almost feel like you're actually trespassing on someone else's personal space (just as the narrator is doing to Coda). Like Davey Wredon's previous 'The Stanley Parable', The Beginner's Guide pushes the boundaries of what a game can be in adopting storytelling techniques not commonly seen in games. It's probably not for everyone, but at this point if it does sound even remotely like your thing - then it probably is, and I can't recommend it enough.

This is the story of a man named Coda. Coda worked for himself in a big building where he was a game programmer and developer. Coda's job was simple: he sat at his desk in his room, and he pushed buttons on a keyboard. Ideas came to him through a monitor on his desk, telling him what buttons to push, how long to push them, and in what order. This is what Coda did every day of every month and every year, and although others might have considered it soul-rending, Coda relished every moment that the ideas came in, as though he had been made exactly for this job.  And Coda was happy.  And then one day, something very peculiar happened. Something that would forever change Coda. Something he would never quite forget.     Aside from the fitting Stanley Parable joke, this game really does speak for any artist who struggle with depression as well as the negative impacts of game developement (or rather just anything artistic in general) it can have on one's life. I recommend you getting this if you want to want observe the nature of how one struggles through it all. Otherwise I wouldn't because it's basicallly another freaking walking simulator.     Though if you aren't a big fan of walking simulators I'd think it's best to avoid it.

First things first, I must say that I completely adored The Stanley Parable. It was a new spin on the concept of a game that I had never seen before. The Beginner's Guide embodies for me, that same concept. I want to say that it is novel and unprecedented, but that might just be because I haven't played enough games of the genre. I highly recommend it, and anyone reading this and still wondering if they should play it or not should stop reading immediately and come back only when they finish the game themselves.  The Beginner's Guide is an emotional journey of analysis and progressive introspection, through a surreal landscape showcasing the power and beauty of the Source engine. The gameplay is simple; the immersion is real. All you have to do is follow the instructions of the narrator, guiding you though a story, packed with ideas not commonly seen in a video game.  One of the things it might inspire you to do, as it did me, is to create something. Play around with the Source engine. Make ideas come to life. The Beginner's Guide might not have the highest replayability value, but it has a large impact. More please.

And yet it feels entirely unique.  I've never really experienced anything like this in interactive storytelling - and I've been an avid gamer since birth. A huge recommendation!

**TL;DR VERSION AT THE END!**  Before I dive in the review, I must absolutely stress that this game is NOT like The Stanley Parable in pretty much any way other than its thougt-provoking nature. While TSP is an actual game with a cohesive narrative, The Beginner's Guide is more of what you could compare to a commentary about a particular game dev's life.  That being said, let's start. I went into The Beginner's Guide completely blind; the only thing I knew about it was that it is made by Davey Wreden, the person behind the EverythingUnlimited studios and the wonderful The Stanley Parable, and that it was about video game development. I bought the game without thinking because TSP holds a very dear place in my heart because of how it shows that video games have tremendous potential as an artform and I was sure that TBG would be similar. I was wrong, but not entirely. As I've said, TBG is basically a commentary made by Davey about a game developper, nicknamed Coda (I say nicknamed because I have reasons to think it is not his real name, I won't give any arguments in order not to spoil anything, but think that Coda sounds a bit like coder). You will play through Coda's games and Davey will be commenting throughout by voiceover.  'Well that's great and all', I can hear you say, 'but why not simply have us play the games outside of the compilation? Furthermore, why do we pay EverythingUnlimited the money that we would owe Coda?'. Well, Coda has never released his games to the public. And that's why the story told by Davey is so interesting. I don't know if you are very familiar with litterature or even art in general, but there are many artists who create pieces and never show them to the public. They keep it to themselves. Why then? What is the purpose of their creation? This is one of the questions asked here in The Beginner's Guide. Throughout TBG, Davey tries his best to explain Coda's games, how they show his personnality and how he was feeling at the time and confronts us with perhaps a vision not everyone will have had about video games. The goal of TBG is not only to have us play Coda's games, it's also to make us understand that a creator always leaves a trace of himself in his creations. In the end, The Beginner's Guide is the tale of a human journey, the one of a creator whose only way of expressing his thougts was through his games and his sorrow when he lost inspiration.   I would love to go on about the game, but I would risk spoiling it for you. It's really something to experience. You may still be asking yourself if you should get this game or not. Well, in my very own opinion I think the price is a bit too much to ask for as a game. But look past the game aspect and you will have yourself something special that may change the way you see video games.  It also depends on what you expect from a game. You may have liked The Stanley Parable and not find any interest in The Beginner's Guide, as they have two very different approaches to making you think about its main topic, TSP being more metaphoric as opposed to The Beginner's Guide being direct. You could compare TSP to a philosophic tale and TBG to a philosophy essay. If you want something thougt-provoking and you're not afraid of sitting down for an hour and a half listening to someone talking while not doing much, this game is definitely for you.  tl;dr version: You like thinking, consider video games as a possible artform and wish to support the dev with your money? Get it! You want an 'actual' game like The Stanley Parable that can be enjoyable without thinking too much? Forget it!

Is it possible to really understand another human being? Is it even meaningful to try? When we try to analyze something, are we just projecting our own biases onto it? These are tall, open-ended questions that The Beginner's Guide tries to answer. What you get out of it, like most things in life, depends on you.  The game opens with Davey Wreden introducing himself as the writer of The Stanley Parable, a work he proudly calls 'absurd'. This game, he says, will be different. Delivering on that promise, The Beginner's Guide asks you not to make a series of choices, but to try and understand where a person was coming from as he created a series of video games. Wreden lets you play these games, frequently interjecting to give you his opinion on what everything means, but what really matters is what you take from the experience.   Traditional gameplay elements are sparse and accusations of being a 'waking simulator' will probably appear in droves, but that shouldn't impede players interested in the process of making and understanding games. The Beginner's Guide is one of the most unique experiences of 2015, staying with you long after you exit the game.

First off. Don't read this if you have not played the game yet. Don't even watch the trailer. Your best bet at enjoying the game is to go at it blind, I know it's a lot to ask, especialy coming from some guy on the internet but please just do it.  So, this game is of a rare fue. And not only for it's interesting storing telling mechanics but also for how intimate it gets, which in the world of games and game related media is almost unheard of. It seems as if Davey, the creator of The Stanley Parable, is jotting all his emotions onto paper then coding it into a game which is honestly very brave especialy in with the current attitude of 'i'm behind a computer screen and so thus I can behave and talk how I want'. This generaly creates a lot of negative criticism even from people that haven't even played the game.  Honestly what this game does well is that it created an emotional connection between the player and the narrator which ,as previously stated, is almost unheard of. Where most games strive to achieve immersion or simply to just be fun this games goal seems to be a emotional vent for the creator and whether you hate it or love it there is no getting away from the fact that it conveys this very well.   Personaly I think that the emotional connection comes from seeing these games from the narrator's perspective, not in the traditional sense but more that you are seeing what he saw when he first played these games Coda made. I won't spoil anything (although I told you to play the game first) but it is obvious to see that what people think or feel are not always seen in the things they create however the game is very good at trying to push the idea that it is, again. No spoilers.  It is interesting to have the narrator walk you through the games and explane them as he saw them and to give his personal interpretations of them although it feels as if he intends for you to make your own as he hasn't got all the answers himself. which brings me to the end of this review and the final point I would like to make.   I think the narrator wants to know what you think. it's wierd to think of it that way but that's what I truely believe. As much as this game seems to be a personal vent for his emotion it also looks as he is looking for some form of guidance to help him understand his friend. Although by the end we see his final opinion on why Coda stopped making games, I think he wants some outside influence and this is one of the only ways he can do it. where you have Youtubers that convey there emotions/opinions via videos, he does it through games and it creates a connection that could otherwise not be achived.  When all is said and done The Beginners Guide is not as much of a game as it is a Vlog on a much more impressive scale. It is amazing how well the creator shows you what he thinks and feels through incredible game design and story telling and for that I applaud him. Good Job! This game is... interesting.  When I first saw this game, and saw that it was made by the same people that made The Stanley Parable, I was all for getting it. The trailer looked nice, and it peaked my curiosity. The game itself was so much more different than what I expected. It's not like any game I've played before because... well, because it tells a story through a series of video games, that seem to have some meaning behind it. Granted, the meanings of these games in this game can be difficult to understand; why did this person make it like this? What was going on in their head? And most of the time it felt empty, there was no objective to these games most of the time, but the way it was made, made these games enjoyable. They introduce a different element than what you see in games today.  I was reading the other reviews of this game, and stumbled upon some that don't recommend this game. Some said that it was just a game about someone that needs therapy. Although this seems true from what you play in the game, I don't think that's a reason why you shouldn't buy the game and play it. Personally, if you like story-rich games, this is still a good one, even if it is someone that's talking about their problems, and their mistakes. Sometimes, if you don't have anyone to talk to, why not find another method of getting stuff off your chest?  The game moves slow, and in the beginning it's pleasant. As the games go on, they get much darker, as the narrator will explain this all to you and tell you his interpretation of why the game maker made it that way. Of course, there's no telling if his representation is the right one, but it is one to make you think. As I was playing this game, I wondered who was this person that made these games, what was he really like? You don't get an answer, but you have to come up with one yourself. Or, you can go with what the narrator thinks of all of it.  I think you should buy this game if you enjoy hearing a story that... might make you cry. Overall, this game makes it enjoyable in its own way, each game in this game has a different atmosphere, and you get to see what Coda might've been like.

First thing's first - This is not The Stanley Parable 2. That's hopefully apparent by the trailer for the game, but in case it's not, it's worth mentioning. Wrenden's storytelling style is still present here, and it won't feel entirely unfamiliar, but if you come into this expecting the same level of dark humor and branching pathways, you may come out of it disappointed.  The Beginner's Guide is, I guess, what can be described as a more 'standard' example of the 'Walking Simulator' genre, and if you have strong opinions on the genre one way or the other, you should already know what you're getting here. This is akin to a guided tour through a museum exhibit, and if that sort of thing turns you off, you're not likely to find much enjoyment here.  That said, if that is the sort of thing you're open to, The Beginner's Guide is incredibly well presented and paced, and (in my opinion) incredibly effective as a piece of art. To say too much about it would be to rob it of some of its value, but it is the kind of thing that, if you're affected by this sort of thing, will likely sit with you long after you've reached the end.  Davey's narration and commentary, I think, is what really makes this game work. The conversational tone of the commentary gives enough of a casual feeling that it comes off as him trying to have a conversation with you as the player, and I think that honestly makes all the difference here. His cutting at just the right points adds enough of a personal humanizing touch to the experience to what could otherwise easily have wound up feeling a little too weird, stuffy, or pretentious.  The game is short - you can easily do everything in one sitting in about an hour or so, and the replayability is entirely up to whether or not you're the kind of person who sees any value in re-experiencing something a second time with added context. You're not going to find any alternate endings here, but this might be the kind of game worth playing twice for certain people. But even with that in mind, this is several hours worth of playtime at best, so if that's the sort of thing you like to take into account while looking at the price tag, it's worth mentioning.  As for me, I absolutely got my money's worth out of this, and I'd love to see more like this from Wrenden in the future. I'd definitely rank it on the higher end of the genre. I'd recommend it to anyone who finds the the premise even a little interesting... but they should also understand what it is they're getting going into it.  The Beginner's Guide isn't for everybody. But for the people it is for, it's extremely good.

I see a few negative reviews here, and I feel the need to talk about why you might not like this game. If you're more interested in going against the narrator...it's not the game for you. If you need to believe the box you're placed in to begin with, this is not the game for you either. This is a walking sim and a highly personal story, given a frame mechanic about being about some unknown game developer named Coda. To me, the conceit is pointedly thin. The narrator edits games constantly, and if you know games, you know that you don't...really edit other people's games. This game is about the narrator, and his understanding of himself and his needs. Coda, and his games, ultimately, don't matter. And, yes, people who make games do make games like this...pointless little exercises in understanding, so the games Coda makes aren't the realm of a game someone who makes games to make them happy would make, but that doesn't matter. This game is definitely a game about feelings, that takes you to a very unexpected place. It's a very...emotional ride, and at least for me, I didn't see where it was taking me. I knew from moment one that the narrator was to be questioned. Is Coda a real person? What's the narrator's real relationship with Coda? There's a lot of room for interpretation, but one thing can be certain. There is something wholey and unmistakingly wrong through the who game, and it's the questions that raises, not the gameplay or the conceit itself that are needed. You don't have to play The Stanley Parable to play this, and honestly, I wonder if having played that game may take away a bit of the impact of this game as you're already at questions with the narrator and its hallways to begin with. But, this is a, wholy, beautiful game. Play it alone, when you have an hour to kill, and a little time to reflect.

I often get the sense that people visit game review sites to obtain a sense of validation, or maybe to glean some sort of elements of interpretation from an external party – something out of which their own opinion might be formed. Find a reviewer that agrees with your own perception, and you'll feel validated. Find one who doesn't and you have a spectrum of reactions to choose from – from acceptance to angry retaliation. Insert any number of “GameSpot sucks!” or “IGN gives perfect tens to everything!”-related comments here...  Validation seems to be the core conceit of Davey Wreden's The Beginner's Guide, his follow-up to the critically acclaimed metanarrative experience of a few years back – The Stanley Parable. It also touches on other personal themes, such as depression or acceptance, but it felt less cohesive than its predecessor to me. To understand that, the structure of it all needs to be observed.  The Beginner's Guide is presented to us as a curated and scrubbed-off compilation Wreden has made of a friend's one-off game development projects. Davey grounds himself in reality as both the narrator and curator of the experience, and even provides us with a Gmail address, in case the need to discuss our thoughts or interpretations does arise. As for said friend, whom he only refers to as “Coda”, this particular presence is less a character than a set of tics and emergent themes. The game functions both as a, well, game of sorts, but also as a kind of sped-up game development seminar. What starts as a simple and fairly slapdash Counter-Strike map ends as a sprawling train station, the level of detail and effort picking up as one goes along.  Through it all, Wreden seems hell-bent on finding some sort of deeper meaning behind Coda's mechanical or aesthetic fixations and even goes so far as to bypass entire sections of these semi-finished experiences, as impatient as he seems to be to whisk the visitor along to his interpretation of Coda's works. Bridges are made, movement constraints are removed, nonsensical level sections are bypassed – it's presented as Wreden bringing clarity and immediacy to Coda's deliberately obtuse game design fixations, but it takes a back seat whenever the first one feels the need to praise or pontificate on the second's approach to deliberate hurdles or puzzle-solving. It all feels almost... useless, honestly, seeing as I simply cannot see what any developer would gain out of using gratuitous constraints. It isn't even research, past a certain point – it strikes me as Coda, serving as the requisite Socially Inept and Withdrawn Game Developer, choosing to aggrandize mechanics that have no rhyme or reason, no true purpose.  At one point, Wreden whisks us through a few prison-themed levels. You're trapped in a minuscule skybox which doubles as a room, and the walls that are plastered with cloud textures lead out to an upside-down well. The shape and general theming of the prison change, but that's essentially it: you're trapped.  I understand that video games offer a terriffic medium for self-expression, and several developers have not only written the proverbial book on the subject, they've improved it. Dear Esther, Gone Home, Neverending Nightmares, Among the Sleep – there's a bevvy of titles out there that eschew the need to provide traditional mechanics. ♥♥♥♥ First-Person Shooter concerns, we've been getting Barthesian Analysis Simulators!  I don't mean that in a mocking way – I'm glad for any attempt to use hardware and software in a means that injects a dose of literacy or much-needed depth into the medium. What does chafe against me, though, is the notion that someone like Coda would feel the need to use deliberately obtuse mechanics in the context of a series of games that was never meant to leave his hard drive! Oh, everyone can do whatever it is they feel like on their own machines, of course, but why create Byzantine environments if you're going to restrict yourself to a tiny room? It's difficult to put into words, but there's a point in the game where my empathy towards Coda dwindled to nothing. I no longer saw someone trying to verbalize their social anxiety or depression (as claimed by Wreden) through game mechanics, I saw intentional denial of external solutions and, well, general intellectual masturbation. Coda's minigames stopped striking me as being about the struggles of someone with a neuroatypical framework to fit in with a world where interaction is more valuable than metaphors expressed in a game engine; and started coming across as navel-gazing.  “I am troubled,” the game says. “I have issues. My inner thoughts are turning dark and disturbing. I need help but cannot bring myself to get it. I can't stop making games, yet the process is killing me.”  Earnestness bleeds away, and soon all I heard was “I am today's Tortured Poet, suffering through the Source Engine as Poe, Baudelaire and Nerval once did through the written word. Watch me play my sorrowful violin of recycled mechanics being presented as being meaningful! Hear me, fellow sufferers of anxiety!”  At the same time, The Beginner's Guide wants to feel like some guy poking around with the modern-day toy which is every open-source game engine ever. It wants to feel disjointed and it also wants to feel meaningful. I perceived a dichotomy in there, and it left me with a feeling of aggravation. I thought the game would end in a specific manner, which I won't spoil, and it only threw one serious curveball at me. The epilogue's change in focus reframes the entire experience and again, Wreden wants us to feel some sort of epiphany, to come out of the experience with the abovementioned thoughts on personal validation. Is it alright if someone creates unplayable games for the pure sake of creating unplayable games? Is it fine if you never release anything online? How private can you be in a medium where everything has to be shown or at least sketched out?  Only the last two questions interested me, the first one almost struck me as a stroke of masochism and an insult to the principles of game design. No creator would ever break their own levels – even the most disjointed of modern art pieces has a perspective from which a cohesive whole can be discerned.  To put it simply, there's a difference between a Rothko painting and an arbitrarily unclimbable staircase. The Rothko painting uses a single line across a white canvas to achieve its desired goal, to go through its expected process. It's not unfinished; the process is that single red line. On the other hand, The Beginner's Guide acts as though, say, electrifying the museum's main gates were part of the exhibit. There's a painting in there, you have to see it to obtain enough information to be able to land a cohesive opinion – but you can't enter the museum, since touching the front doors is painful. Then Davey Wreden the Helpful Tour Guide attempts to reify that electrified door, shuts down the power, follows you all the way to the painting you came to see and then blathers all over it, as if you had the inability to form some sort of opinion!  The game achieved its goal in that it made me feel something – and that does it credit, seeing as today's games rarely bother with empathy – but I rather would have felt something more noble, more involved, than the vague need to pull out my fake Arnold Schwarzenegger voice and yell “Davey, stahp eet!”  It gets a cautious thumbs-up.

### EXPECTATION ###  So you see that there's a new game of the developer of The Stanley Parable - you really did enjoy that wonderfully crafted creative experimental video game experience about a man named Stanley; a parable on the topic Choice in video games as well as on Life itself. Crafted in a way that hasn't been done before. You watch the trailer for The Beginner's Guide and you think: 'Ok. Kinda interesting, but hm... can't be better and more avant garde than The Stanley Parable. Let's wait for a while until it's cheaper.'   I was totally wrong.   ### SURPRISE ###  Not completely comparable to the previous game, it deals with so much more topics - topics that go way deeper than Choice or Free Will. In a broader sense, Davey vivisects not only the Video Game Industry, but the drive that keeps us humans alive - what keeps our pursiut, our ambition to live, the reasons we give up on life or keep going on.   From here on there will be Spoilers. Let me say one last thing: 'PLAY THIS GAME UNBIASED / UNPREJUDICED. Otherwise you will definately regret it!'   -------------------------- ---- SPOILER ALERT ---- --------------------------  I've played this game twice within two days now. First time alone, second time with a friend - we had a long discussion and thought-exchange afterwards. To make it short: I haven't seen a game yet, which deals with these much critical and actual topics in a sometimes sublte sometimes direct way. It goes from critics on the video game industry and on the players themselves towards topics of depression and schizophrenia. There's so much meaning hidden between the lines - it's like most (if not all) the Coda Games are a statement in itself: The lack of falling damage which the player normally expects in video games lets us carefully 'climb' down the boxes (Chapter 7, Down). The playability of video games concerning the players expecations and patience (several chapters; labyrinths, puzzles). And the way it deals with sensitive topics is breathtaking. So carefully.   ### VERDICT ###  The Beginner's Guide created a new Genre. It's kinda the evolution of novels, film and videogames. It is not comparable to other games yet. Most people won't regret buying it - there's just so much to get from it. It's a piece of modern art.

The game is played running through one developer's various interactive levels made in 2009 to 2011, but narrated by the other developer in 2015 as he used to...uhh...experience them?  I have to say this is really emotional. Like weirdly personal stuff. A deeply intimate tour of depression, antisocial tendencies, self-loathing for one man, and the feelings of abandonment and horrible guilt for the other. I guess I'm recommend it lol but it probably isn't for everyone. Purely from a value standpoint, it's not bad asking for $10 for about 90 minutes of 'gameplay' that you would otherwise never encounter in a video game, ever. Very unique. It's definitely asks the player to remain open minded about the medium itself and to explore an otherwise aimless game for the opportunity to dive deeply into two person's behaviors and thoughts for the sake of experiencing something.

This is a game in which you walk through one strange mini world after another while being lectured to by some dude who's weirdly obsessed with lampposts. If you dislike games in which your skills and actions are irrelevant (other than having to move to progress the plot), you probably won't like this one either. If you're hoping for something like Stanley Parable, be warned that The Beginner's Guide is linear, serious rather than funny and doesn't have choices/multiple endings.  Pros: + Atmosphere/Story: Pretty interesting 'plot' that makes use of its medium in the sense that I feel like it would not work equally well as a book or audiobook. + Exploration: You get to see and interact with lots of surreal places. + Good Voice-Acting / Sound  Cons: - Really short (90 min for me, and I took my time), I might replay it once but in general there's probably not a lot replay value to it. - Walking Simulator: As mentioned above, you could watch someone else play it and see and hear exactly the same things. +/- Story: Definitely not everybody's cup of tea (check out some of the negative reviews for more details), but if what you have heard so far made you curious I would recommend trying it just for the unique experience.

It leaves you feeling hollowed out and almost horrified but somehow I also feel renewed - energized about my work. I simeltaneously need the longest nap ever to recooperate but I also want to draw until my hands fall off.  At its essential core the game is telling you this - be honest to your art work. The creation has to be FOR you - the minute it becomes not for you, for pleasing other people, is the second you've lost yourself. I'm thankful for this game, despite my tears.

While this is a Not Recommended review, I can really only recommend it for other game developers. I do not recommend it for the average gamer. It is, in places, visually interesting. The narrator (and author) is actually a decent voice actor. It seems to attempt a deeper meaning than is readily clear and it may be compelling for some to think about. There are many theories and ideas about it's meaning popping up, and it has created some interesting conversations. There is some value in generating this kind of open table discussion, so far without any input from the author, but it boils down to third-party speculation about one individual's personal head space. Interesting for a philosophical symposium, but ultimately futile. Most reviews and threads I've read about it could be summarized with the statement 'Because I do not understand it, it must be deep and meaningful.' The author seems to have a message he wants to convey, but struggles with how to convey it. I think this was a rather personal game, made as a message, or apology, to a specific person. There is an extant interview with the author that backs this theory. The narrator is a sort of devil's advocate, playing as the person he wants to apologize to, while the fictional second character is the author himself. A kind of role-reversal, as if to say 'See, I know how you feel, and I'm sorry.'  In any event, it didn't leave me with a good feeling. The parts where the second character was railing at the narrator for needing a purpose or point in a game, felt like the author himself railing at gamers in general. In fact, it gave me the feeling that gaming itself is a futile waste of time and life. A strange message to convey in a game, and a depressing notion for a gamer. Even the part with all the notes left by fictional gamers felt like a condescending mockery of gamers in general, as if we are all a bunch of selfish, immature cretins demanding that the emotionally complex genius of a developer gut his poor soul for our entertainment. It seems to me The Beginner's Guide to disenfranchising your customer base. A feeling of unease, almost nausea, builds throughout. There was some potency in the final sequence, but mostly I was just glad for it to be over. After all that, the mopey song at the end just felt like cynical manipulation. What I think in a nutshell: the few negative reviews for The Stanley Parable really got to him and this is the result, a figurative middle finger extended to gamers. I could be entirely wrong, but that's the feeling it gave me. If it were free to play I might recommend it, but no one should pay actual money for what amounts to an expiremental, self-indulgent foray into a game developer's emotional state, personal life, and thought process. The message I got was -- making games is hard, emotionally taxing and psychologically draining for the tortured genius. Though a game may be published, it was not made for you, but is simply an expression of the author, a catharsis of artistic talent and technical skill which you do not deserve and could never possibly understand. It reminds me of juvenilia, the kind of poetry that teenagers write; deeply personal, self-centered, overwrought tripe that has little to no value for most other human beings.

The Guide isn't a game. It's another one of those increasingly popular 'walking simulator' narrative games. This one was created by the same developer of the amazingly funny 'Stanley Parable', which was one of the few narrative games I actually feel is worth playing (but only once, since the magic is lost on replaying it). Unfortunately, The Beginner's Guide doesn't even offer that much.  Purportedly an exploration of an avant garde game designer's own developmental history, it is arguably an autobiography or just a tale-tale. What it isn't, is particularly enjoyable as it consists entirely of walking through poorly rendered levels of never-released test-games while the narrator drones on at you. The biggest - and only - mystery is what it all means: was the developer, as the narrator insists, a misunderstood genius whose games were his only way of expressing his insecurities? Or was the 'developer' just a representation of the narrator's own struggle with maintaining his creativity? Or is it something else? It's an interesting enough tangle that - fortunately - isn't wrapped up neatly by the end of the game but left to the player's own interpretation. Unfortunately, that is all the game has going for it. The 'mini-games' aren't games at all, so there isn't anything to actually DO in this game except walk continually forward. There's no point to exploration since there's nothing to find, and the game (purposely) lacks in visual polish. It's all well and good to leave the meaning of the game up to the player, but that only works if the player cares enough about the product to spare it some thought. Unfortunately, the presentation was so tiresome that I just preferred to walk away from it and find something actually INTERESTING to think about.

(No spoilers)  I loved The Stanley Parable and very much wanted to feel the same about The Beginner's Guide, but it just didn't do anything for me. Where TSP was immediately understandable to anyone who'd ever played a game, I don't feel that TBG's story is relatable to anyone who either isn't a content creator or who hasn't experienced a specific sort of anxiety. Most stories are capable of overcoming that boundary and still impacting people who can't personally related, but something about the narrative structure and abstract nature of TBG prevented that from happening. Though occasionally interesting, the plot can't support the game on its own.   Unfortunately, TBG has very little to stand on once its narrative fails. The game can barely be called that - most of the scenes consist of walking around hallyways and boxes with no opportunity for meaningful interaction or failure. What choices there are can be briefly interesting, but don't appear to change anything notable beyond the very short term. The exploration and experimentation that sustained TSP simply aren't here.   Recommended only either for $3 or less or (potentially) for people who've published work. Expect 60-100 minutes of playtime.

It's beauty was anticipating every action I thought was not going to be anticipated. It was the byplay with the narrator, as if we were speaking with each other.
